text: (bright music)

- [Narrator] Many AWS customers
use AWS Secrets Manager
to store database credentials.
Starting from the 1.0.658 version,

AWS Schema Conversion
Tool provides integration
with AWS Secrets Manager.

This means that you can
retrieve database credentials

from AWS Secrets Manager
and use them to connect
to your database in AWS SCT.
To use Secrets Manager, make sure

that you store your AWS
service profile in AWS SCT.

This video shows how to
store database credentials
in AWS Secrets Manager, configure AWS SCT,

and connect to your databases
using the credentials
from AWS Secrets Manager.
We log into AWS Management Console
and choose Secrets Manager.
You can see that we already store

the SQL Server database
credentials in Secrets Manager.
Now, we store a new secret

that includes an Amazon
Relational Database Service
for PostgreSQL database credentials.
We enter the required information,
specify the database type,

and choose Next to
proceed to the next step.
Then we enter the secret name

and proceed with the default
values for other parameters.

You can see that the
secret has been stored
in AWS Secrets Manager.
After the page refresh,

this new secret appears in
the list of available secrets
in AWS Secret Manager.
Now we launch AWS Schema Conversion Tool
on the application settings.
On the AWS service profiles tab,
you can add a new AWS service profile.
To add a new AWS service profile,
enter your AWS access and secret keys,
AWS Region, and the Amazon S3 bucket.

In our case, AWS SCT already
uses the AWS service profile.
We choose Test connection to verify

that AWS SCT can connect
to AWS Secrets Manager
and other AWS services.

We create a new database
conversion project.
Then we add a source database
and choose Microsoft SQL Server.

We enter the connection name
and choose the AWS Secret
from the list of available secrets.
After we choose Populate,
AWS SCT retrieves database credentials

from AWS Secrets Manager
and fills in all the fields.
You can see that AWS SCT connects

to the source SQL Server
database using the credentials
from AWS Secrets Manager.
Now we add a target database
and choose Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL.
We use our second secret from the list
to connect to the target database.

AWS SCT connects to the
target PostgreSQL database

using the credentials
from AWS Secrets Manager.
Now you can use AWS Schema Conversion Tool

to add mapping rules,
create assessment report,
and convert your database schemas.

This completes the overview
of the AWS SCT integration
with AWS Secrets Manager.
Thanks for watching this video.
